result.execSummary:
This case has not been concluded. Unless a judgment of conviction is entered, the defendant is presumed innocent of all charges.

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

records.addlTxt: Status conference on November 14, 2022 at 02:15 pm.

1:21 PM Hearing held via Zoom due to Judge illness- parties agree to proceed. Attorney Andrew I. Martinez in court for Jerry L Ward Jr.  Attorney Cecelia DeMarco for Daniel R. Hess in court for State of Wisconsin. Parties requesting date for Motion Hearing. Any other motions to be addressed at the November 14th Motion Hearing need to be filed no later than November 7th.
Status conference scheduled for November 14, 2022 at 02:15 pm.
Status conference on October 17, 2022 at 01:30 pm.

Information was E-filed with the court and a copy was given to the defendant; Defendant waived reading of Information; Defendant stood mute, Court enters plea of Not Guilty; motions due in 20 days; bail continued.

2:57 PM Defendant Jerry L. Ward Jr. in court, in custody.  Attorney Jeremiah Wolfgang Meyer-O'Day in court for Jerry L. Ward Jr.  Prosecuting attorney Rebekah M. Rennicke in court for the State of Wisconsin. The State moved to find counts 1 and 2 transactionally related.  Court found counts 1 and 2 transactionally related. Law Enforcement officer Corey Nelson duly sworn & testified; Venue Established; Witness ID'd defn; State moves for bindover - made argument; Defense objects to bindover - made argument pertaining to constitutionality; State objected. Court binds case over; bail continued.
